raw_text:
Robertson out to retain Euro lure
 
 Hearts manager John Robertson hopes a place in the knock-out stages of the Uefa Cup could help keep some of his out-of-contract players at the club.
 
 "It could help. If we get through and have another European tie it may encourage players to stay at least until the end of the season," he said. "If we manage to get through it shows how well the club's progressing. "They have to think whether they are going to get other clubs like that should they decide to move on." A win for Robertson's side against Ferencvaros would put them through to the last 32 if Basle fail to beat Feyenoord. "It's very much the player's prerogative but the fact that we've been playing European football for the last three or four years is obviously an incentive," added Robertson. "But we want players who want to play for the football club, who are committed and a run in Europe always helps a little bit." With the game being played at Murrayfield instead of Tynecastle because of Uefa regulations, Robertson sees both positive and negative aspects to the change of venue.
 
 "The pitch is not in the greatest condition. The Heineken Cup game was there at the weekend and the pitch is a bit threadbare," he said. "It's not ideal but it's the same for both teams so we just have to go out and there and perform. That's the most important thing." But he added: "If Tynecastle could have hosted 30,000 it would have been fantastic but that's one of the benefits of Murrayfield - it allows us to bring even more of our supporters into it. "There will be a good atmosphere and the Hearts fans have an important role to play. "We need their encouragement, we need them to get right behind the side and make it as good an atmosphere as possible. "Hopefully the players will respond to that and I know they will because it's a fantastic European night for the club."
llama3.2:1b: Robertson hopes retaining Euro competition could keep some of his out-of-contract players at Hearts, while also showing progress in the club.
He believes winning against Ferencvaros would be beneficial if Basle lose to Feyenoord.
The game will take place at Murrayfield instead of Tynecastle due to UEFA regulations, and Robertson acknowledges the patchy pitch but emphasizes the importance of performance over venue.
llama3.2:3b: Hearts manager John Robertson hopes a Uefa Cup run can keep out-of-contract players at the club, especially if they qualify for another European tie.
A win against Ferencvaros would put them through to the last 32.
Robertson acknowledges the Murrayfield pitch condition but sees it as an opportunity to bring more supporters and create a good atmosphere.
gemma2:2b: John Robertson, Hearts manager, believes playing in the Uefa Cup could encourage out-of-contract players to stay until the end of the season.
A win against Ferencvaros would advance them to the knockout stage and may influence player decisions.
He also sees the change of venue from Tynecastle to Murrayfield as a positive opportunity for supporters to rally behind the team.
qwen2.5:0.5b: John Robertson is concerned about his out-of-contract players, believing a win against Basle could help keep them at the club during Euro Cup rounds.
He believes keeping a player out of contract can make him stay longer at the club if they get through another European tie.
He suggests playing against Basle instead of Tynecastle as it has been played for three or four years and is likely to be beneficial for both teams.
The Heineken Cup game was played there but it's not ideal due to its condition, so he still wants a good pitch.
Bob Brown, the caretaker manager, believes the pitch at Murrayfield isn't in the best condition compared to Tynecastle, which is hosting a Heineken Cup match instead of the full European season.
However, both teams are playing against each other and it's more important that they perform well overall rather than just one game.
Heather Fraser also mentions that the fans have an important role to play by encouraging their team mates and making sure they're as good as possible for a fantastic European night for the club.
Overall, Robertson is trying to encourage his players to remain at the club during difficult times when other clubs may be considering moving on.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Hearts manager John Robertson hopes retaining a place in Europe could encourage some of his out-of-contract players to stay, while playing at Murrayfield is seen as an opportunity to attract more fans.
The match against Ferencvaros will likely put Hearts through to the knockout stage if they win and Basle lose their tie.
Despite venue issues at Tynecastle, Robertson believes the positive atmosphere provided by a packed crowd can help players perform better.
qwen2.5:3b: Hearts manager John Robertson hopes winning in the Uefa Cup could keep out-of-contract players at the club until the end of the season.
Robertson believes a place in knockout stages would encourage players to stay, as it shows how well the club has progressed.
A win against Ferencvaros would secure passage if Basle loses to Feyenoord.
While playing at Murrayfield may have an adverse effect on the pitch, Robertson acknowledges that both teams are affected and emphasizes performing is crucial.
He also highlights the positive aspect of allowing more fans into the match due to Uefa regulations, which he sees as a benefit.
Robertson expects players to respond positively to the enthusiastic crowd.
opencoder:1.5b:
Roberto Retains the Euro Lure

Hearts manager John Robertson plans to keep some of his out-of-contract players at the club.

He said, "If we get through and have another European tie, it may encourage players to stay at least until the end of the season, as they can be keenly positioned for the knock-out stages of the Uefa Cup."
By doing so, he shows them how well the club's progress is being made.
As a win against Ferencvaros could put them through to the last 32 if Basle failed to score, Robertson shows commitment and determination.
"It's a player's right but also an European footballer's obligation," added Robertson, showing enthusiasm for the game played at Murrayfield instead of Tynecastle because of Uefa regulations.
The game being played is marked by its excellent condition on the pitch, which isn't in the worst condition.
The Heineken Cup game was there at the weekend and the pitch was a bit threadbare, but it's still the same for both teams so we have to go out and there and perform.
That’s the most important thing for Robertson.
As they play more European football, they will be able to bring more supporters into Murrayfield.
As with any fantastic European night, the Hearts fans will also be taking part.
With their encouragement, they will know when and why they should move on.
With that, Robertson realizes his vision can't prove successful until he has shown enthusiasm for the game.
He is committed to playing football club, who is committed and a run in Europe always helps a little bit.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Robertson aims to retain some players by securing a spot in Euro cup knockout rounds, encouraging them to stay until the end.
He notes that a successful game could allow them to compete till then.
Venue change to Murrayfield highlights the atmosphere's importance and encourages player engagement, believing it's a great event for the club.
tinyllama:1.1b: In terms of their outlook, the Heart of Midlothian FC has been hoping to retain some of its out-of-contract players in order to keep them in the club.
The team manager, John Robertson, believes that having another European tie could encourage players to stay at least until the end of the season.

However, the fact that they will be playing away from Tynecastle because of Uefa regulations may have a negative aspect as it means less fans are able to support them, but Robertson sees both benefits and drawbacks, stating that the pitch is not in the best condition and Murrayfield offers an even greater atmosphere for supporters.
The match between Heart of Midlothian FC and Basle SC at Murrayfield Stadium on Tuesday evening is scheduled for a European night, with fans encouraged to attend if they wish.
Heart of Midlothian FC's next game will be against Ferencvaros in the Uefa Cup on Wednesday.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Robertson is keen on keeping some of his out-of-contract players at the club if he manages to qualify for the knockout stages of the Uefa Cup.
However, if his team gets through to the next stage, he hopes to keep several key players until the end of the season.
He believes this could be a strategic move that may encourage other clubs to consider staying with their current management.
phi:2.7b: John Robertson hopes winning the Uefa Cup knock-out stages could encourage his out-of-contract players to stay at the club until the end of the season.
He believes playing in Europe helps show how well the team is progressing, and having more fans in attendance will provide a great atmosphere for them.
However, Robertson acknowledges that playing at Murrayfield instead of Tynecastle has its disadvantages, such as the not-ideal condition of the pitch due to previous games.
Despite this, he sees the positive aspects of being able to bring more supporters into the match and believes his players will respond positively to their fans' support.
orca-mini:3b: Robertson hopes hosting a European tie can keep some out-of-contract players at Hearts, but worries about pitch condition and wishes Tynecastle could have hosted more fans.
hermes3:3b: Hearts manager seeking EU cup progress to keep key players, hopes Murrayfield venue for Ferencvaros match could encourage retention.
